From:	jsu1535n@jsu.edu
Sent:	Monday, February 02, 2009 6:28 PM
To:	Tony Teem
Cc:	Lori Liles; Tonya Burton
Subject:	prototype

Hey Y'all,

Tony, you were not in the hall when Tonya, Lori and I had this discussion about
who should do the prototype. Well I emailed Dr. Garrett, and he basically
agreed with what I suggested, which was that Tonya should do the prototype
(preferably in Visio) and hand it to you guys for the GUI design.

Tonya, perhaps you could do the prototype for each method one at a time, then
hand it in to Lori and Tony so that they will always have something to work
with, instead of waiting to do it all at once- or maybe not- just a suggestion.
I'm sure you guys will work something out.

Jaleesa
From:	aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com on behalf of Aaron Garrett [agarrett@jsu.edu]
Sent:	Monday, February 02, 2009 3:16 PM
To:	jsu1535n@jsu.edu
Cc:	Tony Teem
Subject:	Re: prototype/interface question

Absolutely. For the interface design, Tonya should basically be
telling Tony and Lori what to do. Her prototype should specify how it
looks and how it behaves. All Tony and Lori should have to do is make
the interface to conform to the prototype. And I'd rather Tonya did it
in Visio. It's made for that sort of thing. She can get a copy from
the department, if she doesn't have one already.

By the way, Logan is going to be a great asset for the database stuff.
He caught on very fast. You guys aren't going to have to worry about
that part. He seems to be a strong team member.

When we meet as a group for the design, we should be able to get
everything hammered out so that people can split up and work
relatively independently. However, there will be some people with very
little to do during implementation (Tonya, Logan, and Andrew). I think
they would be best served to work on the test plan and maybe a brief
user's manual for the software. That would be a nice addition that the
Dempsey's would appreciate. Of course, that's just my opinion.



Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Jacksonville State University
Jacksonville, AL  36265
agarrett@jsu.edu
256-782-5364
http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett

Attachments:	DiSHAnalysis.odt

I want to meet with the whole group on Monday at 12:30pm. It's time
for the first of what will probably be several lashings of the
semester. The analysis document is far from done. The clock is ticking
here. It needs quite a bit of work, and you and Tony need to put some
people on the different sections. There were more that we talked about
including, I think, and those should be in there. Check your notes.
And when you write this document, think of it this way... I plan to
show this, no matter its quality, to any potential employers who call
me for a reference for you. Your effort here will be rewarded later
and I will be able to give you a sterling recommendation. Lack of
effort here will have consequences beyond this semester. This goes for
the entire team, but I will reserve the majority of the praise or the
lashings for you two.

In any event, I intend to motivate you guys on Monday. Make sure that
everyone is there. No one misses this one. It will be short.

I've gone through the document. It looks significantly better. We're
in good shape to hit the deadline with room to spare now. Some stuff
at the end still needs work in terms of describing the new
functionality and stuff with the database. Make sure Logan and Andrew
finish their stuff, and make sure that the interface components are
described as completely as you can.

You guys should force every one of your team members to read through
the entire document. More eyes means fewer mistakes. I sprinkled
random insults towards Tony throughout the paper (no offense, Tony;
you're my punching bag on this one). So if you turn this thing in and
I find one of them, I'll know for certain that someone dropped the
ball. And don't try the Find function. I was more creative than that.
You'll have to read the whole document to find them.

Just to be clear, you guys are the managers, but that doesn't mean
that you have to do all of the work. Delegate, and follow up. If
something is done well, tell them so. If it's done poorly, tell them
so. But make them do their own work if you can.

By the way, this document is starting to look like something I'd be
happy be happy for the Dempsey's or an employer to see. Well done. But
make sure that you and the team race all the way to the tape. We'll
probably tweak all the way to the deadline, so be prepared. But the
major effort is over. OK. That's your praise for the month. Don't
spend it all in one place.

The design that we put together today is very good. I have a working
prototype now using that design, and it appears to be very localized.
Everyone takes care of their own stuff, so it should be really easy to
make changes and additions as needed. Implementation won't be that
bad, it looks like. But there's plenty more to be done. I'm going to
prototype the database insertion and then finalize the prototype XML
file format. Then I'm stepping away from this for you guys to take and
finish. Ignore the code that I gave you to begin with. I had to change
most of it to fit this new design, but we're better off because of it.
And I thought the first design was good. Man, I was way off. In any
event, I'll give you guys the code I have as soon as it's ready for
the D's to use.

To:	Tony Teem
Subject:	Re: UML class diagram

It looks really good, Tony. I have 2 comments.

First, you can resize the drawing area if you want to get it all onto
one canvas. It's under File -> Page Setup. You might want to make 2
tabs -- one for the full connected and described system and the other
for just the class names and their connections (without all the
methods and stuff). The second one should easily fit onto a printable
page.

Second, don't forget that your system has more stuff than the one that
I gave you. Make sure that everything is accounted for. I'm not sure
what you have or don't have, but make sure to put everything that's
needed in the final product.

you need from me. I'm willing to do whatever to the best of my ability just
let me know.

Logan

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:22 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
> Also, what time tomorrow? is 12:30 good? I'm available all day until 2. Lori
> has to work so I'll have to take some great notes =) Do you want the whole
> group? or just Lori and I? I hadn't really thought about the connection
> between the XML loader and the creation of the experiment... what's the best
> way to do that? i just had a vague idea of a new experiment class that loads
> in all the necessary information. Like she would form each class then pass
> in Lists or variables for the whole program.
>
> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:15 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>> I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should be
>> merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams, schema,
>> and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct assumption?
>>
>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM, Aaron Garrett
>> <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>
>>> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
>>> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
>>> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
>>> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
>>> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
>>> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
>>> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
>>> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
>>> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
>>> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
>>> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
>>> calc, which is misleading).
>>>
>>> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
>>> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
>>> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
>>> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
>>> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
>>> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
>>> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
>>> questions:
>>>
>>> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
>>> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
>>> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
>>> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
>>> experiment system?
>>>
>>> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
>>> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
>>> you're not done with design.
>>>
>>> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
>>> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
>>> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
>>> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
>>> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
>>> revisions.
>>>
>>> A few other issues I see...
>>> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
>>> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
>>> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
>>> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
>>> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
>>> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>>>
>>> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
>>> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
>>> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
>>> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
>>> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
>>> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
>>> button.
>>>
>>> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
>>> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
>>> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
>>> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
>>> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
>>> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
>>> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
>>> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
>>> here.
>>>
>>> Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
>>> have by then?
>>>
>>> Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck it,
>>> losers!
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>> Assistant Professor
>>> Computer Science
>>> Jacksonville State University
>>> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>> agarrett@jsu.edu
>>> 256-782-5364
>>> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 7:27 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>> > Will you review what we have in our API so far and offer up some
>>> > tips/suggestions? I think we are either finished or very close to being
>>> > finished.
>>> > Tony
>>> >
>>> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:45 PM, Aaron Garrett
>>> > <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>> > wrote:
>>> >>
>>> >> Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be
>>> >> called
>>> >> Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job
>>> >>
>>> >> The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the caller
>>> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then I
>>> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>> >> Assistant Professor
>>> >> Computer Science
>>> >> Jacksonville State University
>>> >> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>> >> agarrett@jsu.edu
>>> >> 256-782-5364
>>> >> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:37 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>> >> > A couple of questions.
>>> >> > A precondition is a description of something that MUST happen before
>>> >> > this
>>> >> > method can be invoked right?
>>> >> > What is a postcondition?
>>> >> >
>>> >> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 12:13 PM, Aaron Garrett
>>> >> > <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com> wrote:
>>> >> >>
>>> >> >> That looks like you're on the right track, yes.
>>> >> >>
>>> >> >>
>>> >> >> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>> >> >> Assistant Professor
>>> >> >> Computer Science
>>> >> >> Jacksonville State University
>>> >> >> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>> >> >> agarrett@jsu.edu
>>> >> >> 256-782-5364
>>> >> >> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>> >> >>
>>> >> >>
>>> >> >>
>>> >> >> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 12:07 PM,  <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>> >> >> > I just named it something so it would have a name. I believe this
>>> >> >> > is
>>> >> >> > along
>>> >> >> > the lines of what you are looking for. Lori and I will be working
>>> >> >> > on
>>> >> >> > this
>>> >> >> > most of the evening.
>>> >> >> >

>From:	Tony Teem [evilsax@gmail.com]
Sent:	Friday, February 20, 2009 12:31 AM
To:	Logan Moore
Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

I was under the impression that you were going to accept it as it's own
class.. for example, we pass you the whole experiment class with all of it's
subclasses and information and you use whatever get methods we have created
to pull from the file and send to the database. I don't know how databases
work exactly so if this is incorrect I need to know! This may be a better
question for Dr. Garrett.
We need to meet tomorrow, with or without Garrett, all of us that can make
it. There are some details that we all need to agree upon. Not knowing
database really sucks right now, I can't wait to take it next semester.  And
if you take it with me I'll be your best friend since you are getting all of
this practice now =)

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 10:24 PM, Logan Moore <loganjmoore@gmail.com> wrote:

> am dense but I'm kinda having a hard time thinking of this as in classes. I
> think I keep trying to think of it as a database, so I'm going to explain
> how I think it should work and then if you will please steer me straight.
>
> Ok the DB class I provide you should have 2 methods in it, you and lori
> will take the information and pass it to me as what? a string, or would you
> pass everything to me via separate methods like setfirstname etc... I am
> just wondering if I need to create a method to get and set every variable
> needed in the database, or if I can just create an insertDB method and a
> retrieveDB method. If the latter is how it's supposed to be would you be
> passing it as a string and would it be structured the same everytime so I
> could just use a delimiter or something to parse it and insert the data into
> a mysql query?

>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:14 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>
>>>> crap, that last part was for Dr. Garrett, not you.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:10 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>
>>>>> I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should
>>>>> be merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams,
>>>>> schema, and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct
>>>>> assumption?
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:09 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>>>>>> From: Aaron Garrett <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>>>>> Date: Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM
>>>>>> Subject: Re: DiSH Program API
>>>>>> To: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
>>>>>> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
>>>>>> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
>>>>>> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
>>>>>> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
>>>>>> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
>>>>>> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
>>>>>> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
>>>>>> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
>>>>>> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
>>>>>> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
>>>>>> calc, which is misleading).
>>>>>>
>>>>>> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
>>>>>> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
>>>>>> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
>>>>>> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
>>>>>> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
>>>>>> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
>>>>>> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
>>>>>> questions:
>>>>>>
>>>>>> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
>>>>>> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the
>>>>>> database?
>>>>>> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
>>>>>> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
>>>>>> experiment system?
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
>>>>>> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
>>>>>> you're not done with design.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
>>>>>> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
>>>>>> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
>>>>>> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
>>>>>> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
>>>>>> revisions.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> A few other issues I see...
>>>>>> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
>>>>>> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
>>>>>> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
>>>>>> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
>>>>>> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
>>>>>> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
>>>>>> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
>>>>>> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
>>>>>> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
>>>>>> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
>>>>>> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
>>>>>> button.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
>>>>>> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
>>>>>> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
>>>>>> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
>>>>>> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
>>>>>> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
>>>>>> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
>>>>>> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
>>>>>> here.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
>>>>>> have by then?
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck
>>>>>> it, losers!
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>>>>> Assistant Professor
>>>>>> Computer Science
>>>>>> Jacksonville State University
>>>>>> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>>>>> agarrett@jsu.edu
>>>>>> 256-782-5364
>>>>>> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
>>>>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 7:27 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>>>> > Will you review what we have in our API so far and offer up some
>>>>>> > tips/suggestions? I think we are either finished or very close to
>>>>>> being
>>>>>> > finished.
>>>>>> > Tony
>>>>>> >
>>>>>> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:45 PM, Aaron Garrett <
>>>>>> aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>>>>> > wrote:
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >> Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be
>>>>>> called
>>>>>> >> Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >> The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the
>>>>>> caller
>>>>>> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then
>>>>>> I
>>>>>> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>>>>> >> Assistant Professor
>>>>>> >> Computer Science
>>>>>> >> Jacksonville State University
>>>>>> >> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>>>>> >> agarrett@jsu.edu

>>>>>> >> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >>
>>>>>> >> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:37 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>
>>>>>> wrote:
>>>>>> >> > A couple of questions.
>>>>>> >> > A precondition is a description of something that MUST happen
>>>>>> before
>>>>>> >> > this
>>>>>> >> > method can be invoked right?
>>>>>> >> > What is a postcondition?
>>>>>> >> >
>>>>>> >> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 12:13 PM, Aaron Garrett

From:	Logan Moore [loganjmoore@gmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, February 19, 2009 10:25 PM
To:	Evilsax@gmail.com
Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

Hey thanks,
I am attaching a visio file of a class diagram for the database. I guess I
am dense but I'm kinda having a hard time thinking of this as in classes. I
think I keep trying to think of it as a database, so I'm going to explain
how I think it should work and then if you will please steer me straight.

Ok the DB class I provide you should have 2 methods in it, you and lori will
take the information and pass it to me as what? a string, or would you pass
everything to me via separate methods like setfirstname etc... I am just
wondering if I need to create a method to get and set every variable needed
in the database, or if I can just create an insertDB method and a retrieveDB
method. If the latter is how it's supposed to be would you be passing it as
a string and would it be structured the same everytime so I could just use a
delimiter or something to parse it and insert the data into a mysql query?

Thanks Logan

>>>>> To: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
>>>>> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
>>>>> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
>>>>> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
>>>>> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
>>>>> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
>>>>> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
>>>>> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
>>>>> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
>>>>> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
>>>>> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
>>>>> calc, which is misleading).
>>>>>
>>>>> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
>>>>> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
>>>>> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
>>>>> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
>>>>> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
>>>>> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
>>>>> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
>>>>> questions:
>>>>>
>>>>> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
>>>>> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the
>>>>> database?
>>>>> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
>>>>> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
>>>>> experiment system?
>>>>>
>>>>> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
>>>>> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
>>>>> you're not done with design.
>>>>>
>>>>> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
>>>>> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
>>>>> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
>>>>> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
>>>>> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
>>>>> revisions.
>>>>>
>>>>> A few other issues I see...
>>>>> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
>>>>> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
>>>>> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
>>>>> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
>>>>> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
>>>>> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>>>>>
>>>>> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
>>>>> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
>>>>> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
>>>>> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
>>>>> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
>>>>> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
>>>>> button.
>>>>>
>>>>> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
>>>>> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
>>>>> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
>>>>> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
>>>>> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
>>>>> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
>>>>> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
>>>>> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
>>>>> here.
>>>>>
>>>>> Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
>>>>> have by then?
>>>>>
>>>>> Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck
>>>>> it, losers!

>>>>> aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>>>> > wrote:
>>>>> >>
>>>>> >> Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be
>>>>> called
>>>>> >> Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job
>>>>> >>
>>>>> >> The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the
>>>>> caller
>>>>> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then
>>>>> I
>>>>> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".
>>>>> >>

>>>>> >> > A precondition is a description of something that MUST happen
>>>>> before
>>>>> >> > this
>>>>> >> > method can be invoked right?
>>>>> >> > What is a postcondition?
>>>>> >> >
>>>>> >> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 12:13 PM, Aaron Garrett

From:	Tony Teem [evilsax@gmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, February 19, 2009 9:55 PM
To:	Lori Liles
Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

I asked him what time, i'll let you know.

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:53 PM, Lori Liles <lileslori@gmail.com> wrote:

> OK, so that's a lot to take in all at once.  Do we need to meet tomorrow to
> polish it up?  I can meet after work if need be.  Just let me know...if you
> want to run by his office at 11:30 I can manage that, but I can't stay very
> long.  I never told them exactly when I would be at work, I just said around
> lunch.  Just let me know.
>
>
>
>
> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:14 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> crap, that last part was for Dr. Garrett, not you.
>>
>>
>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:10 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>>> I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should
>>> be merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams,
>>> schema, and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct
>>> assumption?
>>>
>>>
>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:09 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>>>> From: Aaron Garrett <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>>> Date: Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM
>>>> Subject: Re: DiSH Program API
>>>> To: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
>>>> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
>>>> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
>>>> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
>>>> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
>>>> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
>>>> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
>>>> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
>>>> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
>>>> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
>>>> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
>>>> calc, which is misleading).
>>>>
>>>> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
>>>> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
>>>> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
>>>> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
>>>> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
>>>> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
>>>> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
>>>> questions:
>>>>
>>>> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
>>>> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
>>>> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
>>>> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
>>>> experiment system?
>>>>
>>>> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
>>>> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
>>>> you're not done with design.
>>>>
>>>> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
>>>> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
>>>> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
>>>> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
>>>> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
>>>> revisions.
>>>>
>>>> A few other issues I see...
>>>> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
>>>> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
>>>> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
>>>> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
>>>> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
>>>> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>>>>
>>>> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
>>>> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
>>>> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
>>>> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
>>>> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
>>>> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
>>>> button.
>>>>
>>>> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
>>>> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
>>>> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
>>>> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
>>>> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
>>>> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
>>>> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
>>>> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
>>>> here.
>>>>
>>>> Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
>>>> have by then?
>>>>
>>>> Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck it,
>>>> losers!
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>>> Assistant Professor
>>>> Computer Science
>>>> Jacksonville State University
>>>> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>>> agarrett@jsu.edu
>>>> 256-782-5364
>>>> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 7:27 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>> > Will you review what we have in our API so far and offer up some
>>>> > tips/suggestions? I think we are either finished or very close to
>>>> being
>>>> > finished.
>>>> > Tony
>>>> >
>>>> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:45 PM, Aaron Garrett <
>>>> aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>>> > wrote:
>>>> >>
>>>> >> Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be
>>>> called
>>>> >> Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job
>>>> >>
>>>> >> The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the caller
>>>> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then I
>>>> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".
>>>> >>
>>>> >>
>>>> >>
>>>> >> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>>> >> Assistant Professor
>>>> >> Computer Science
>>>> >> Jacksonville State University
>>>> >> Jacksonville, AL  36265

Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:14 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:

> crap, that last part was for Dr. Garrett, not you.
>
>
> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:10 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should be
>> merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams, schema,
>> and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct assumption?
>>
>>
>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:09 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>>>
>>>
>>> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>>> From: Aaron Garrett <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>> Date: Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM
>>> Subject: Re: DiSH Program API
>>> To: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>
>>>
>>>
>>> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
>>> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
>>> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
>>> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
>>> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
>>> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
>>> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
>>> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
>>> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
>>> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
>>> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
>>> calc, which is misleading).
>>>
>>> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
>>> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
>>> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
>>> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
>>> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
>>> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
>>> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
>>> questions:
>>>
>>> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
>>> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
>>> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
>>> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
>>> experiment system?
>>>
>>> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
>>> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
>>> you're not done with design.
>>>
>>> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
>>> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
>>> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
>>> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
>>> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
>>> revisions.
>>>
>>> A few other issues I see...
>>> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
>>> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
>>> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
>>> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
>>> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
>>> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>>>
>>> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
>>> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
>>> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
>>> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
>>> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
>>> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
>>> button.
>>>
>>> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
>>> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
>>> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
>>> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
>>> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
>>> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
>>> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
>>> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
>>> here.
>>>
>>> Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
>>> have by then?
>>>
>>> Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck it,
>>> losers!
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>> Assistant Professor
>>> Computer Science
>>> Jacksonville State University
>>> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>> agarrett@jsu.edu
>>> 256-782-5364
>>> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>>

>>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 7:27 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>> > Will you review what we have in our API so far and offer up some
>>> > tips/suggestions? I think we are either finished or very close to being
>>> > finished.
>>> > Tony
>>> >
>>> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:45 PM, Aaron Garrett <
>>> aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>>> > wrote:
>>> >>
>>> >> Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be
>>> called
>>> >> Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job
>>> >>
>>> >> The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the caller
>>> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then I
>>> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>>> >> Assistant Professor
>>> >> Computer Science
>>> >> Jacksonville State University
>>> >> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>>> >> agarrett@jsu.edu
>>> >> 256-782-5364
>>> >> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >>
>>> >> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:37 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>>> >> > A couple of questions.
>>> >> > A precondition is a description of something that MUST happen before
>>> >> > this
>>> >> > method can be invoked right?
>>> >> > What is a postcondition?
>>> >> >
>>> >> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 12:13 PM, Aaron Garrett
>>> >> > <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com> wrote:

From:	Tony Teem [evilsax@gmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, February 19, 2009 9:22 PM
To:	Aaron Garrett
Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

Also, what time tomorrow? is 12:30 good? I'm available all day until 2. Lori
has to work so I'll have to take some great notes =) Do you want the whole
group? or just Lori and I? I hadn't really thought about the connection
between the XML loader and the creation of the experiment... what's the best
way to do that? i just had a vague idea of a new experiment class that loads

in Lists or variables for the whole program.

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:15 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:

> I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should be
> merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams, schema,
> and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct assumption?
>
> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM, Aaron Garrett <
> aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
>> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
>> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
>> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
>> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
>> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
>> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
>> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
>> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
>> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
>> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
>> calc, which is misleading).
>>
>> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
>> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
>> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
>> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
>> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
>> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
>> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
>> questions:
>>
>> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
>> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
>> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
>> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
>> experiment system?
>>
>> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
>> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
>> you're not done with design.
>>
>> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
>> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
>> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
>> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
>> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
>> revisions.
>>
>> A few other issues I see...
>> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
>> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
>> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
>> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
>> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
>> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>>
>> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
>> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
>> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
>> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
>> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
>> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
>> button.
>>
>> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
>> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
>> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
>> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
>> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
>> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
>> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
>> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
>> here.
>>
>> Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
>> have by then?
>>
>> Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck it,
>> losers!
>>
>>
>>
>> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>> Assistant Professor
>> Computer Science
>> Jacksonville State University
>> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>> agarrett@jsu.edu
>> 256-782-5364
>> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>>

>> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 7:27 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>> > Will you review what we have in our API so far and offer up some
>> > tips/suggestions? I think we are either finished or very close to being
>> > finished.
>> > Tony
>> >
>> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:45 PM, Aaron Garrett <
>> aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>> > wrote:
>> >>
>> >> Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be
>> called
>> >> Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job
>> >>
>> >> The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the caller
>> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then I
>> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".
>> >>
>> >>
>> >>
>> >> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>> >> Assistant Professor
>> >> Computer Science
>> >> Jacksonville State University
>> >> Jacksonville, AL  36265
>> >> agarrett@jsu.edu
>> >> 256-782-5364
>> >> http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett
>> >>
>> >>
>> >>
>> >> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 5:37 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>> >> > A couple of questions.
>> >> > A precondition is a description of something that MUST happen before
>> >> > this
>> >> > method can be invoked right?
>> >> > What is a postcondition?
>> >> >
>> >> > On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 12:13 PM, Aaron Garrett
>> >> > <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com> wrote:
>> >> >>
>> >> >> That looks like you're on the right track, yes.
>> >> >>
>> >> >>
>> >> >> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>> >> >> Assistant Professor

From:	Tony Teem [evilsax@gmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, February 19, 2009 9:16 PM
To:	Aaron Garrett
Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should be
merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams, schema,
and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct assumption?

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM, Aaron Garrett
<aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>wrote:

> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
> calc, which is misleading).
>
> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
> questions:
>
> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
> experiment system?
>
> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
> you're not done with design.
>
> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
> revisions.
>
> A few other issues I see...
> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>
> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
> button.
>
> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
> here.
>
> Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
> have by then?
>
> Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck it,
> losers!
>
>

> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then I
> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:10 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:

> I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should be
> merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams, schema,
> and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct assumption?

> On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:09 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>> From: Aaron Garrett <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>> Date: Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM
>> Subject: Re: DiSH Program API
>> To: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>
>>
>>
>> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
>> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
>> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
>> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
>> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
>> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
>> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
>> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
>> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
>> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
>> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
>> calc, which is misleading).
>>
>> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
>> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
>> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
>> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
>> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
>> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
>> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
>> questions:
>>
>> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
>> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
>> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
>> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
>> experiment system?
>>
>> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
>> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
>> you're not done with design.
>>
>> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
>> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
>> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
>> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
>> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
>> revisions.
>>
>> A few other issues I see...
>> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
>> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
>> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
>> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
>> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
>> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>>
>> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
>> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
>> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
>> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
>> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
>> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
>> button.
>>
>> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
>> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
>> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
>> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
>> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
>> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
>> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
>> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
>> here.
>>

>> have by then?

>> aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
>> > wrote:
>> >>
>> >> Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be
>> called
>> >> Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job
>> >>
>> >> The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the caller
>> >> of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then I
>> >> promise to give you (postcondition)".

I was under the impression that the Analysis and design document should be
merged together to form one big doc. This will include all diagrams, schema,
and text documents that we have formed so far. Is this a correct assumption?

On Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 9:09 PM, Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com> wrote:

> ---------- Forwarded message ----------

> Subject: Re: DiSH Program API

>
> OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
> variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
> your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
> really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
> to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
> itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
> Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
> participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
> the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
> value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
> though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
> calc, which is misleading).
>
> I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
> actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
> guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
> concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
> is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
> thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
> for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
> questions:
>
> How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
> How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
> How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
> How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
> experiment system?
>
> Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
> head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
> you're not done with design.
>
> The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
> to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
> I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
> there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
> that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
> revisions.
>
> A few other issues I see...
> I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
> controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
> should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
> and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
> experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
> log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.
>
> I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
> JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
> you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
> a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
> mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
> whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
> button.
>
> The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
> this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
> possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
> this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
> the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
> design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
> parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
> certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
> here.

> have by then?

> losers!

From:	Tony Teem [evilsax@gmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, February 19, 2009 9:10 PM
To:	Lori Liles
Subject:	Fwd: DiSH Program API

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Aaron Garrett <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
Date: Thu, Feb 19, 2009 at 8:38 PM
Subject: Re: DiSH Program API
To: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>


OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
calc, which is misleading).

I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
questions:

How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
experiment system?

Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
you're not done with design.

The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
revisions.

A few other issues I see...
I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.

I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
button.

The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
here.

Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
have by then?

Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck it,
losers!



Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Jacksonville State University
Jacksonville, AL  36265
agarrett@jsu.edu
256-782-5364
http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett

From:	Aaron Garrett [aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, February 19, 2009 8:39 PM
To:	Tony Teem
Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

OK. You need to use the Java standard naming scheme for methods and
variables (camel notation like addSomeVariable). I'm doubtful about
your calcIndifPoint (which I'd rather just spell out all the way,
really) being in the method classes. Here's the question that you have
to ask: Can the DoubleLimit class determine the indifference point
itself? The answer, if you think about it, has to be "no". Why?
Because to find the indifference point, you have to interact with the
participant. The DoubleLimit class doesn't do that. That's the job of
the DoubleLimitUI class. But the UI classes could easily give that
value to the method classes via the setters/getters. In that case,
though, it would just be a getIndifferencePoint method (rather than
calc, which is misleading).

I'm not too concerned about the design document being flawless,
actually, because it's going to be a good learning experience for you
guys when you have errors in it that you didn't anticipate. I'm mostly
concerned about the parts on the edges being right (where integration
is going to happen). Make sure that you spend as much effort and
thought as you can on those parts, because they're the critical ones
for us. Make sure you have clear in your mind the answers to these
questions:

How will Jaleesa give the Experiment object to you and Lori?
How will you give the Experiment object to Logan to add to the database?
How will Logan allow you to let an experimenter log in?
How will you allow Logan's data output system to integrate with your
experiment system?

Remember, you have to kind of write the code in broad strokes in your
head. If there's any part that seems foggy when you do that, then
you're not done with design.

The document looks pretty good, considering we didn't have very long
to do it. I'd like to see those UML pictures in the final version. And
I want everyone to understand that once the design document is in,
there will have to be a very compelling reason to change something
that it says. Making additions later is easier than deletions or
revisions.

A few other issues I see...
I'm not convinced that the Experiment class should be the main
controlling frame for the program. That seems like something that
should be its own class. A class (in general) should do one thing only
and should do it fully. If the Experiment class represents the
experiment and its data, then it shouldn't also have to take care of
log-ins and menus and stuff. That needs to be separated out.

I would be in favor of stating that OptionUI extends from
JRadioButton. That way, you could make some assumptions about things
you can do with it (like determine if it's selected, make it a part of
a button group, etc.). Just because it extends JRadioButton doesn't
mean it has to LOOK like a radio button. We can make it look like
whatever we want. It just means that it logically behaves like a radio
button.

The OO design stuff just takes time to learn. And other people with
this same problem might come up with a completely different, and
possibly better, design than what we are working on. I'm certain of
this, though. When you guys get to the end of this project and see all
the dots connected, you'll be able to see the holes in the initial
design and maybe see how they could have been avoided. There are still
parts of this project that I don't quite see to the end of, but I'm
certain that it can all be done within the framework we have outlined
here.

Why don't you guys come by the office tomorrow and show me what you
have by then?

Btw, I have a working prototype finished, and it is uber-sweet. Suck it, losers!



Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Jacksonville State University
Jacksonville, AL  36265
agarrett@jsu.edu
256-782-5364
http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett

From:	Aaron Garrett [aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, February 19, 2009 5:45 PM
To:	Tony Teem
Subject:	Re: DiSH Program API

Precondition: what MUST be true before the function can safely be called
Postcondition: what WILL be true after the function does its job

The pre/post-conditions represent a contract of sorts with the caller
of your function. You say "if you promise to do (precondition) then I
promise to give you (postcondition)".



Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Jacksonville State University
Jacksonville, AL  36265
agarrett@jsu.edu
256-782-5364
http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett

From: Aaron Garrett <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
Date: Wed, Feb 18, 2009 at 2:39 PM
Subject: Re: class diagram
To: Jaleesa Elston <jejaggedge@gmail.com>
Cc: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>


To add parameters to those functions, you need to click the operation
and then click "properties..." and a new window will pop up that has
choices like "parameters" and "exceptions", which is where some
important stuff should go. The stuff you wrote looks right, but you
really want to put that into the document itself underneath your
picture that you're making. Take a look at the (very simple) attached
file. I want something better than this for each class you guys make.
I'm copying Tony on this so that he'll know what I'm expecting for his
part, too.

> On Mon, Feb 23, 2009 at 7:34 PM, Aaron Garrett <aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>
> wrote:
>>
>> OK. I didn't compile it, but I'm pretty sure I can spot the errors by
>> just looking at it.
>>
>> First, it's not an error, but we need to adhere to the Java standard
>> of capitalizing class names. So "time" and "timeUnits" should be
>> "Time" and "TimeUnits".
>>
>> Second, you have made the attributes static, which means there is only
>> one copy of that attribute for ALL instances, instead of one copy per
>> instance. So, I'm sure that your test main is showing that both
>> instances eventually have the value of 12, even though you only set
>> the second one to be 12. That's because there is only one "value"
>> variable that is shared among all instances you ever create. Setting
>> it for one sets it for all.
>>
>> To fix it, just take out the static keyword on both of those
>> attributes. Generally, attributes should only be static if they are
>> also constant (so "final static").
>>
>>
>> Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
>> Assistant Professor
>> Computer Science

From:	Aaron Garrett [aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com]
Sent:	Monday, February 23, 2009 7:35 PM
To:	Tony Teem
Subject:	Re: Question

OK. I didn't compile it, but I'm pretty sure I can spot the errors by
just looking at it.

First, it's not an error, but we need to adhere to the Java standard
of capitalizing class names. So "time" and "timeUnits" should be
"Time" and "TimeUnits".

Second, you have made the attributes static, which means there is only
one copy of that attribute for ALL instances, instead of one copy per
instance. So, I'm sure that your test main is showing that both
instances eventually have the value of 12, even though you only set
the second one to be 12. That's because there is only one "value"
variable that is shared among all instances you ever create. Setting
it for one sets it for all.

To fix it, just take out the static keyword on both of those
attributes. Generally, attributes should only be static if they are
also constant (so "final static").


Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Jacksonville State University
Jacksonville, AL  36265
agarrett@jsu.edu
256-782-5364
http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett

Create and edit documents, spreadsheets and presentations online, from  
anywhere you have Internet access.

once, in real time.

secure servers, even if something happens to your hard drive, your  
documents are protected.

From: Tony Teem <evilsax@gmail.com>
Date: Sun, Mar 1, 2009 at 9:55 PM
Subject: Re: Milestones
To: Tonya Burton <tnb1987@gmail.com>


1. Investigator is it's own class I believe, I need to get this cleared up.
2. Race is an enumerated data type... like in Java when you do
setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE)
on a JOptionPane.. the DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE is an enumerated data type also.
So, for example, if you wanted to set the Race on a participant, you would
pass in the variable Races.WHITE or Races.OTHER

3. Choice is an Option.

I'll look it over again once you have

From:	Tony Teem [evilsax@gmail.com]
Sent:	Sunday, March 01, 2009 9:56 PM
To:	Tonya Burton
Subject:	Re: Milestones

1. Investigator is it's own class I believe, I need to get this cleared up.
2. Race is an enumerated data type... like in Java when you do
setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE)
on a JOptionPane.. the DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE is an enumerated data type also.
So, for example, if you wanted to set the Race on a participant, you would
pass in the variable Races.WHITE or Races.OTHER

3. Choice is an Option.

I'll look it over again once you have

On Sun, Mar 22, 2009 at 7:24 AM, Aaron Garrett
<aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com>wrote:

> OK. I fixed the code and committed the changes. The problem was that
> you should only have one timeUnits enumerated type. The Time class
> expects a constructor that takes a float and a Time.timeUnits type.
> You were passing it a float and a Method.timeUnits type. Just because
> your Method.timeUnits enumeration happened to be identical to the
> Time.timeUnits enumeration doesn't mean that they're interchangeable
> to the compiler (because it isn't smart enough to understand that). So
> you just need to prepend "Time" to the beginning of any use of your
> timeUnits enumeration (outside of the Time class; inside, you can just
> call it "timeUnits"). For instance
>
> Time.timeUnits tu = Time.timeUnits.SECONDS;
>
>
>
>

From:	Aaron Garrett [aaron.lee.garrett@gmail.com]
Sent:	Sunday, March 22, 2009 7:24 AM
To:	Tony Teem
Subject:	Re: Code Help?

OK. I fixed the code and committed the changes. The problem was that
you should only have one timeUnits enumerated type. The Time class
expects a constructor that takes a float and a Time.timeUnits type.
You were passing it a float and a Method.timeUnits type. Just because
your Method.timeUnits enumeration happened to be identical to the
Time.timeUnits enumeration doesn't mean that they're interchangeable
to the compiler (because it isn't smart enough to understand that). So
you just need to prepend "Time" to the beginning of any use of your
timeUnits enumeration (outside of the Time class; inside, you can just
call it "timeUnits"). For instance

Time.timeUnits tu = Time.timeUnits.SECONDS;




Aaron Garrett, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Jacksonville State University
Jacksonville, AL  36265
agarrett@jsu.edu
256-782-5364
http://mcis.jsu.edu/faculty/agarrett

From:	Tony Teem [evilsax@gmail.com]
Sent:	Monday, March 16, 2009 5:03 PM
To:	Lori Liles
Subject:	Re: DiSH

My classpath under environment variables is:
.;C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.6.0_05\lib\ext\QTJava.zip;C:\Program
Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_10\bin\miglayout-3.7.jar

So all you really need is miglayout-3.7 because it contains everything else
listed.. aka the total package.

when you compile with ant it makes an executable .jar file inside the dist
folder.I think his is runnable, just make sure you have microsoft SQL
installed. (most computers already have it)
I made some changes to the main.java file. Added the jfilechooser and such,
so if you haven't made any changes to that file then just update it.

From:	Lori Liles [lileslori@gmail.com]
Sent:	Monday, March 16, 2009 12:12 PM
To:	Tony Teem
Subject:	DiSH

Hey!  I have made some major modifications to the documents.  There are
still 29 errors, which mostly deal with the miglayout.  For some reason, it
just does not like the miglayout.  I haven't looked at it too closely.  I've
been comparing our files to Dr. Garrett's and copying and pasting things we
need and modifying them to work with ours.  I changed the enumerated reward
type to a string, because it just seems to work a lot better.  Especially
with how many errors there were as I kept getting farther into it.  I'm
going to try and work on it more today and see if I can't figure out all the
errors.  I'm also going to look at the reading widget code and maybe try
adding it in.  I'm going to check and see if he has all of the functionality
we need as far as what things we need from it.  Did you or Jaleesa send him
an email letting him know what all we need from the widget?  Well, I'm gonna
eat lunch now and take a break from all these errors...there were about 50,
so I narrowed a good bit down.  Hope you had a good day at work.  Oh yeah,
how do you run files with ant apache.  Just curious.  Also, can we run Dr.
Garrett's prototype, since we don't have the database?  Or can I download
whatever I need for the database?  I was just wanting to run his to look at
it more.  Thanks!

Lori

Hello all,

a quick change to it. Its done now.

(Logan, Tonya, Andrew)

Ok so the Dempsey's said we were missing some demographics...ones they put
in the feedback. I'll forward the email to you guys. I know Logan & Andrew
would have to make changes to the database design, and Tonya, you would have
to change the interface a little bit, but besides that, it's no biggie. Tony
and Lori, I'm not real sure if this will affect what yall are doing, but if
